bibl.title: Letter from James E. Peabody to Friends of the Yellow Fever Heroes of 1900, November 15, 1926

div1.p: Peabody describes efforts to obtain pensions for Kissinger and for widows of yellow fever commission participants.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Friends of the Yellow Fever Heroes of 1900, November 15, 1926

opener.dateline:
The Morris High School
166th. and Boston Road, N. Y. City,
November 15, 1926.
opener.salute: To the Friends of those Yellow Fever Heroes of 1900:

div1.p:
You have all been so generous in your assistance during this past
week, and you have expressed so much interest in the case of John R.
Kissinger, that I venture to send you this statement of events up to
date.

My correspondence with Mr. Kissinger began about fifteen years
ago. The many letters received from him all breathe the same spirit
as that contained in a letter written December 4, 1912, in which he
said:

“It was a big triumph and I am glad that my humble self was one
to take a small part in it, not to be called a hero or a martyr,
but to feel in my own heart that I helped in saving thousands
of lives and millions of dollars, and making it possible to
accomplish the building of one of the greatest engineering works
of the world, the Panama Canal.”

On September 1st., on my way home from a five-months' trip for
travel and study in the West, I spent an hour with Mr. Kissinger in
his little home in Andrews, Huntington County, Indiana. I was deeply
impressed with his self-effacing modesty, and with the courage dis-
played by the man and his wife during all these past twenty-five years.

Dr. Wendell C. Phillips, President of the American Medical Associa-
tion, secured an appointment for me with Dr. Hubert Work, Secretary
of the Interior, and so, with the approval of Dr. Tildsley and Prin-
cipal Bogart, I left for Washington Friday afternoon, Nov. 15. On
reaching Princeton that evening, I spent an hour or more with Prof.
E. G. Conklin. He urged me to get in touch with Dr. Theobald Smith,
who over twenty years ago examined Mr. Kissinger after he was strick-
ened with myelitis of the spine, and if possible to enlist the aid of
Dr. William H. Welch in Baltimore. The next morning at the Rockefel-
ler Institute, four miles out of Princeton, Dr. Smith expressed the
greatest interest in Kissinger, and promised to find if possible the
record of his visit at South Bend, Indiana, (Kissinger's former home).

Saturday evening in Baltimore I talked with Dr. Howard A. Kelly
(the author of “Dr. Reed and Yellow Fever”) and with Dr. W. H. Howell
(the newly appointed Director of the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene
and Public Health). Both were very helpful in their advice, and they
told me how to reach Dr. Welch, who on Sunday generously gave two
hours of his time. (He was intimately acquainted with all the mem-
bers of the Yellow Fever Commission, appointed in 1900 by President
McKinley). He wrote three very urgent letters to the Washington au-
thorities, and these, together with two others from Dr. Kelly, proved
of invaluable assistance.

Dr. Hubert Work, Secretary of the Interior, Surgeon General Ire-
land of the Army, Surgeon General Cumming of the Public Health Ser-
vice, and Colonel Kean (who was in charge of sanitation in Cuba in
1900 and who followed closely the details of the yellow fever exper-
The Yellow Fever Heroes of 1900 (2)
iments) were more than cordial, and it needed no words of nine to en-
list their interest in Kissinger, since they were all familiar with
his story, except in its later details. After some discussion all
agreed with Colonel Kean's suggestion that every possible influence
should be brought to bear upon Congress to secure legislation that
would give to Mrs. Walter Reed, Mrs. Jesse Lazear, and Mrs. James
Carroll, and to Mr. and Mrs. Kissinger an annuity of $250 per month
for the rest of their lives. (The three widows receive at the pres-
ent time $125 each per month, and Kissinger $100).

Dr. Vernon Kellogg, Secretary of the National Research Council,
the office staff of Science Service (in the absence of Dr. Slosson),
the Veterans' Bureau, and Dr. William E. Ritter, President of the
Scripps' Foundation promised to do all they could to bring this mat-
ter to the attention of the public.

I had three long talks with Mrs. Reed, and from her and from Col.
Kean I gained invaluable first hand information relative to the event
of those memorable six months of 1900 in Cuba. (Since her husband's
death Mrs. Reed has had a monthly income of $125 from the Government
and $100 interest from a fund raised in her husband's memory; she has
a single room in an apartment hotel in Washington, and she and her
daughter have been obliged for years to earn money by art work in em-
broidery).

In 1916, while teaching in the Summer Session of the University of
California, I had the son of Dr. Lazear in one of my classes. He in-
troduced me to his mother and his young sister. Mrs. Lazear told of
the struggle she was having to meet her bills and to educate her chil-
dren with the sum received from the Government.

You do not need to be told that special legislation is not easy to
secure from Congress. In view, however, of the urgent need of all
the four families that would be benefitted by it, everyone with whom
I have talked has expressed the belief that prompt action should be
urged.

We trust that you will send us your suggestions as to the next
steps that ought to be taken.
With deep gratitude for the help you have already given, I remain,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, James E. Peabody,
Head of the Department of Biology,
Morris High School, N. Y. City.
